article_title: Cytomegalovirus Seropositivity Does Not Affect the Outcome of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation with Intensive Monitoring and Modern Anti-Viral Therapy
session_type: Clinical Care - Acute and Chronic GVHD, Infectious Complications, and Immune Reconstitution of Transplantation
abstract_text: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), an important cause of mortality after allogeneic HSCT in the past, is now controllable with sensitive monitoring techniques and drugs such as valganciclovir and foscarnet. However, some groups still report that CMV seropositivity influences the outcome adversely. P<0.0001). Patient or donor CMV status did not affect transplant-related mortality, relapse, or survival, and the outcome of the P+D+, P+D−, P−D+ and P−D− groups was identical. Not a single death was attributable to CMV infection or adverse effects of anti-viral therapy. Bone Marrow Transplant 2006 ; 38 : 95 –100 ). We conclude that intensive monitoring for CMV reactivation, effective anti-viral drugs, and intensive supportive therapy have eliminated the adverse influence of CMV-positivity on the outcome of allogeneic HSCT.
